glosses: With the -in reflexive suffix, derives nouns from verbs.

examples.text: öt- (“to pass through, to make noise, to ask”) + -ün + -ç → ödünç (“loan, any thing borrowed”)
bas- (“to press, to step on”) + -ın + -ç → basınç (“pressure”)

glosses: Derives nouns from some verbs, where the reflexive form replaced the main form and the suffix -in has lost function.
With the -in reflexive suffix, derives adjectives from verbs, even though the verbs may not have reflexive forms.

examples.text: kork- (“to fear, to be afraid”) + -(un)ç → korkunç (“frightening”)
gül- (“to smile, to laugh”) + -(ün)ç → gülünç (“funny, ridiculous”)

etymology: From Ottoman Turkish ـج (-c), as a result of phonetic change from the combination of -in (reflexive suffix) and -iş (reciprocal suffix), hence it is often classified as one suffix as -ınç.
